quiz.title: AP Physics 2
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2, Quiz 10: PV Cycles and Gas Processes
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Ideal Gas Law, PV Diagrams, Work, Heat, Cycles

questions.question: A closed chamber filled with a gas that is modeled as ideal has a movable piston of area $A$. The graph above of pressure $P$ as a function of volume $V$ shows three processes that make up cycle $XYZX$ through which the gas is taken. Process $ZX$ is isothermal. What is the force exerted on the piston by the gas during process $XY$?
questions.explanation: Process $XY$ is isobaric (horizontal line at pressure $P_1$). The force exerted by the gas on the piston is given by $F = P \times A$. Since pressure is constant at $P_1$, the force is $P_1A$.

questions.question: During which process in the $XYZX$ cycle is no work done on or by the gas?
options: D) Work was done on or by the gas during every process
questions.explanation: Process $YZ$ is isochoric (vertical line), meaning volume is constant. Work $W = \int P \, dV$ is zero when $\Delta V = 0$.

questions.question: During which process in the $XYZX$ cycle is the amount of work done on the gas equal to the amount of energy that the gas exchanges with its surroundings through heating or cooling?
options: D) None of the processes; the amount of work done on the gas is always greater than the amount of energy that the gas exchanges with its surroundings through heating or cooling.
questions.explanation: Process $ZX$ is isothermal. For an ideal gas, internal energy depends only on temperature, so $\Delta U = 0$. From the first law, $\Delta U = Q - W_{on}$, we have $0 = Q - W_{on}$, so $Q = W_{on}$.

questions.question: A container is filled with an ideal gas at a high gauge pressure and sealed with a cork of radius $R$ that has been inserted into a circular opening of radius $R$. The force exerted on the cork by the gas has magnitude $F$. If the radii of the opening and cork are increased to $2R$, what will be the magnitude of the new force exerted on the cork by the gas?
questions.explanation: Force on the cork is given by $F = P \times A$, where $A = \pi R^2$ is the area of the cork. When the radius is doubled to $2R$, the area becomes $\pi (2R)^2 = 4\pi R^2 = 4A$. Since the pressure $P$ remains the same, the new force is $4F$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You understand PV cycle analysis, work in different processes, isothermal heat-work equality, and how force depends on area for a fixed pressure.
scoreMessages.70: Good grasp. Review: 1) Force = P×A in isobaric processes, 2) Work = ∫P dV, zero if ΔV=0, 3) ΔU=0 in isothermal ⇒ Q=W, 4) Force is proportional to area if pressure constant.
scoreMessages.50: Needs review. Focus on: Work calculation from PV diagram, distinguishing isobaric/isochoric/isothermal processes, first law for ideal gas, and force-area-pressure relationships.
scoreMessages.0: Start with basics: Force on piston or cork = pressure × area, work done = area under PV curve, isothermal means constant T, adiabatic means no heat exchange.
